s1: This course will provide an introduction to the field of Human-Computer Interaction and will introduce students to key interaction and experience design paradigms, approaches and methods.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.

s1: The course will equip students with theory, methods, and techniques to investigate different design situations, develop novel design ideas, and ask critical questions about the role of technology in society.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.

s1: Characterise key aspects of human-computer interaction, such as interaction design, the user experience, and user interfaces.
s2: Identify core aspects of operating systems and networks irrespective of the specific system at hand.

s1: Differentiate between design paradigms, approaches, and methods and explain their applicability to different design contexts.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.

s1: Investigate the activities and practices of a design space using design research methods, to identify opportunities and issues for design intervention.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.

s1: Ideate, prototype, and evaluate novel technology design ideas and their use in context.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.

s1: Critically reflect on the role of technology in society, including issues of power, agency, and representation in design.
s2: Select appropriate modeling techniques, tools and mechanisms to solve a range of problems in concurrent and distributed systems.
